ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learn a lot about the environment and energy solutions that won't harm it.
I learnt about different types of energy sources and their applications. It provided me with a more well-rounded view over electric vehicle, solar vehicle and other new technology.

I learned a lot about the overall energy system - where we get our energy, how it impacts the environment, et cetera. The future technologies and outlook was also presented, as well as some talk on policy.

- policy analysis
- basic energy calculations
What environmental science is and what we need to focus in this type of subject
The environmental problems wordwide and technologies related to environment.

I learned a lot about the environment and what factors are contributing to global warming, the impacts of climate change, and most importantly the forces (political, economics, etc.) that drive changes in environmental policy. The guest speakers also gave insights and exciting research findings.

Greater integrated understanding of energy sources and production technologies, plus an in-depth understanding of my final presentation topic, electric cars. A great review of useful high school physics and math, plus an introduction (to me) to climate physics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strength of this course is that it encompasses different perspectives regarding energy use from scientific technology to policy-making.
In parts that consist of some physics concepts, professor could slow a bit for everyone to catch up.

Strengths: Prof Prober is super kind and knowledgeable, and he brings in a variety of really special guest lecturers. 

Weaknesses: not exactly a weakness, but most of the lectures are devoted to qualitative content (don't think we did a single numbers related problem) but the homework is almost entirely quantitative.  I personally didn't mind because I learned a lot from lectures but some students I'd imagine would have more trouble with this.

strengths
- informative
- good policy discussion

weaknesses
- can be a bit dry at times

I couldn't find any weakness during the course.

Professor was so passionate and kind with all questions students had. TA system was also great.
Strengths were the guest speakers and the group presentation. Weakness was the exam time which was not enough, in my opinion, but most people finished it.

Strengths: The PSETs were quite helpful in having us synthesize "hard" and "soft" concepts from the class. Weren't too hard as long as you allowed yourself substantial time for them. Dr. Prober is a kind and caring man who tried to make our classroom an open environment for questions. 
Weaknesses: 3.25 hours of a STEM lecture is rather brutal, especially online. Would have liked to have some alternative ways of engaging during our class time, like talking through concepts/problems in small groups or watching more videos. Prober's slides were not always clear or organized and we ended up speeding over some things and rehashing others multiple times. Lectures didn't always prepare us for the PSETs, so a lot of self-teaching was necessary in my case.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because difficulty of this course is suitable for a student who learns about energy and environment for the first time.
Yes - the professor, TA, and guest lecturers are all wonderful. You'll learn a lot about our energy system and the environment.
Sure, if they're interested in climate policy this is the perfect primer course for them.
I would definately recommend this course to someone who is interested in environmental technologies. I am quite sure that he would get a lot of knowledge about it.

Yes, certainly. Take this class. You get to learn a lot without a lot of stress. Also the professor and the TA were very responsive and were phenomenal. The class is designed to give you the best chance to succeed.

For a non-STEM student looking for a SC credit: Probably yes, if they enjoyed high school math and physics, as my main learning occurred through research and calculations during the PSETs. If you learn best through in-class engagement, this course is not necessarily organized for active participation and you might not love the disorganized slides. All in all, it was not a bad class.
